content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Brian Jackson: Well, I was born in Charleston, South Carolina, and I've been here most of my life, though I did move around a bit as a kid. My parents were both working-class folks who didn't go to college, but they always pushed me to do better. I grew up in a small, tight-knit neighborhood where everyone knew each other, and I remember spending a lot of time playing outside with friends, riding bikes, and exploring the woods behind my house. I was pretty quiet as a kid, more of an observer than a talker, but I had a real passion for reading and learning. I guess that's where my love for education came from. I went to a public high school, and even though it wasn't the best, I managed to get into a state university on scholarship. I studied political science, which was a bit of a surprise to my parents, but I always had a strong interest in how things work in society. After college, I landed a job in public policy, which has kept me busy ever since. I've never married, and I don't see myself rushing into that anytime soon. I enjoy my independence, and I like to keep things simple. I speak a bit of Spanish from growing up around a lot of immigrants in my community, and I've always been interested in learning more about different cultures. Life hasn't been without its challenges, but I've always tried to stay positive and make the most of what I have.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Brian Jackson: Yeah, there was definitely a crossroads. I was in my second year of college, studying political science, and I had the chance to either stay on the path I was on or take a different route. I had been offered a job at a local nonprofit that worked with immigrant communities, helping them navigate public services. It was a pretty low-paying gig, but it was meaningful work, and I felt like it aligned with my values. At the same time, I had a chance to intern with a state senator's office, which would have given me more political experience and possibly a clearer path to a career in government. I was torn because I didn't want to ignore the needs of the people in my own community, but I also knew that if I wanted to make real change, I needed to be in a position of influence. In the end, I chose the nonprofit job. It was tough financially, and I had to take on extra work to make ends meet, but it taught me so much about the real-world challenges people face. That experience really shaped my perspective and solidified my belief in grassroots activism over traditional politics. I still work in public policy, but I approach it with a lot more empathy and a deeper understanding of the people I'm trying to serve.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Brian Jackson: I think it was a conscious choice, but not in the way people usually mean. I didn't sit down and make a dramatic decision with a list of pros and cons. It was more like, over time, I started to see the patterns in my own values and the kind of work that truly mattered to me. I realized that I didn't want to be part of a system that felt distant from the people I grew up around. I wanted to be in the thick of it, helping people navigate the same system that had always been a bit of a mystery to me. That choice wasn't just about the job—it was about who I wanted to be and what kind of impact I wanted to have. I think that's why it stuck with me so much. It wasn't just a decision; it was a reflection of who I was becoming.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Brian Jackson: Absolutely, I think I was lucky to have a few people in my life who saw things in me that I didn't always see in myself. My high school teacher, Mrs. Delaney, was one of them. She was the one who encouraged me to apply for that scholarship to college, even though I wasn't sure I could afford it. She believed in me when I didn't believe in myself. And then there was my friend Marcus, who worked at the nonprofit I eventually joined. He was the one who really showed me what it meant to be grounded in the community. Without people like them, I don't know if I would have had the courage to take that path. I think it's important to recognize that we don't always do it alone, and that the people around us can shape our choices in ways we don't even realize at the time.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Brian Jackson: I don't have a partner or children right now, and I don't think I'm in a rush to change that. I've always valued my independence, and I like the freedom that comes with living on my own terms. That said, family is still really important to me. My parents are both in their 60s now, and we stay in touch regularly. They've always been supportive, even if they don't always understand the path I've taken. My mom still works part-time at a local store, and my dad retired a few years ago after working construction. They live in a small town a couple hours away, and I visit them whenever I can. I also have a few cousins who I keep in touch with, and we often get together for holidays or big events. I think family is about more than just blood relations—it's about the people who have been there for you through thick and thin. I'm grateful for the ones I have, and I hope to one day be someone others can count on in the same way.

Going through those interview questions brought a lot of clarity to how my life has unfolded. Reflecting on my childhood, education, and the choices I've made, I see how deeply rooted my values are in the community I grew up in. The crossroads I faced in college wasn't just about a job—it was about aligning my work with my beliefs, and that decision has shaped who I am today. I'm grateful for the people who supported me along the way, like Mrs. Delaney and Marcus, because they helped me see the path I was meant to take. Even though I'm not married or have children, my family remains a central part of my life, and I'm proud of the life I've built on my own terms.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Brian Jackson: My sister, Claire, is someone I haven't mentioned yet. She's a few years younger than me, and we've always had a pretty close relationship, even though we've taken different paths in life. She moved to New York after college to work in fashion, and while I admire her drive and creativity, I think we've always had a bit of a disconnect because of the different lifestyles we've chosen. She's more of a free spirit, always chasing new experiences, while I've always preferred a more grounded, stable life. That said, we still keep in touch, and I think she looks up to me in her own way. I know she's always been proud of me for making my own way, even if our lives don't look anything alike. I respect her for taking risks, and I think she respects me for finding my own path without compromising who I am. Family, in the end, is about understanding and accepting each other, even when we're not the same.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Brian Jackson: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been really important to me over the years. Marcus, the guy I mentioned earlier, is still one of my closest friends. We met in college, and even though we've taken different career paths, we still get together for coffee or go on long walks where we talk about everything and nothing. He's the kind of person who always knows when I need to be reminded of what's truly important. Then there's Lena, a colleague from the nonprofit I worked at. We started off as coworkers, but over time, we became good friends. She's someone who challenges me to think differently and keeps me grounded in the work we do. I also have a few other friends from college who I stay in touch with, though we don't see each other as often as I'd like. They're all people who have helped me grow in different ways, and I'm grateful for their presence in my life. I think friendship is like family in some ways—you don't always have to be together all the time, but you know you can count on each other when it matters.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Brian Jackson: I live in a neighborhood just a few blocks away from where I grew up, which feels like a full circle in some ways. It's still a tight-knit community, though it's changed a bit over the years. There are more young families now, and some of the old storefronts have been replaced by new businesses, but the sense of community remains strong. I live in a small apartment above a local bookstore, which is run by an old friend of mine, Sam. He's a retired teacher who always had a passion for books, and it's been great to support him in this second chapter of his life. The neighborhood has a real mix of people—longtime residents, college students, and even some artists who have set up studios in the old warehouses nearby. I enjoy the diversity here, and it's always interesting to see how people from different backgrounds come together. It's not perfect, of course—there are always challenges with gentrification and rising costs—but I feel like I'm part of something that's still rooted in the values I grew up with. It's comforting to know that even as things change, there's still a sense of belonging here.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Brian Jackson: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. There's a sense of familiarity and mutual respect among the neighbors. I know most of the people who live around me, and there's a real unspoken understanding that we're all trying to make the best of this place. Of course, like anywhere, there are moments when things feel tense—maybe a loud argument late at night or a break-in nearby—but overall, I think the community looks out for one another. I've never had any real issues, and I've always felt like I could walk the streets without worry. That sense of safety is important to me, especially since I've never been one for big cities or high-crime areas. It's one of the reasons I chose to stay close to where I grew up—it feels like home, and home is where I feel most at peace.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Brian Jackson: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the upside, I love the sense of community and the way people still take the time to know each other. It's not the kind of place where you just pass by strangers—you wave, you say hello, you might even stop for a chat. That kind of connection is something I really value. Plus, being close to where I grew up means I can still see the changes over time, and it's interesting to watch how the neighborhood has evolved while still keeping its soul. On the downside, the cost of living has gone up, and it's gotten harder to afford things like groceries and rent. I've had to be careful with my budget, especially since I don't have a partner or family to share expenses with. There are also times when I feel like I'm stuck in a cycle—working the same kind of job, living in the same kind of place, and not sure if I'm moving forward or just staying in place. But I try not to let that get me down. I remind myself that stability isn't always a bad thing, and that I have a lot to be grateful for. I've built a life that's mine, and I think that's something to be proud of.

Going through the recent interview questions about my family, friends, and neighborhood brought a lot of clarity about how deeply connected I am to the people and places that have shaped me. When talking about my family, I realized how much I value the relationships I've built, even if they look different from what others might expect. Not having a partner or children doesn't define me—it's just another part of the life I've chosen, and I'm proud of the independence and stability I've built for myself. When I reflected on my neighborhood, it felt like coming full circle. Living close to where I grew up gives me a sense of belonging and safety that I can't find anywhere else. The community here, with its mix of old and new, reminds me of the values I've always held close. I may not be where I thought I'd be in life, but I'm content with who I am and the life I've built on my own terms.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Brian Jackson: A typical week for me is pretty consistent, though I like to mix things up a bit to keep things interesting. I work full time at a nonprofit focused on community development, so most of my days start around 8 or 8:30 in the morning. I usually have a cup of coffee and read the paper while I eat breakfast—something I picked up from my dad. My work days are pretty structured: meetings, planning sessions, and a lot of community outreach. I enjoy the variety of tasks, but I also have my slow days when I'm just trying to get through the paperwork. In the afternoons, I like to take a walk around the neighborhood or stop by the bookstore where Sam works. I've gotten into the habit of reading a few chapters of a book before heading home. On the weekends, I try to spend time with family or meet up with friends. Sometimes I'll go for a long walk with Marcus or help my parents with something around their house. I also like to cook on the weekends—my mom taught me a few of her recipes, and I've been trying to refine my own style. It's not the most exciting life, but it's steady, and I feel like I'm exactly where I need to be.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Brian Jackson: I work full time at a nonprofit organization called Community Roots, which focuses on helping low-income families access essential services like housing, healthcare, and education. My role is pretty varied—I do a mix of policy research, community outreach, and program coordination. I work Monday through Friday, usually from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m., though I often stay a bit later when there's a big project or meeting coming up. I've been with the organization for about six years now, and it's been a rewarding experience. I get to see the direct impact of the work we do, which is something I really value. It's not always easy—there are days when the bureaucracy feels overwhelming and the challenges seem insurmountable—but I keep going because I know that even small changes can make a big difference in people's lives. I also do some freelance writing on the side, mostly for local publications, which helps keep me engaged with the community in a different way. It's not a huge income, but it's enough to live comfortably, and it gives me a sense of purpose that I wouldn't get from just any job.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Brian Jackson: Outside of work, I also have a few routines that help me stay grounded. I try to get up early most mornings, even on weekends, and take a short walk before starting my day. It's something I picked up from my dad, who always said that a fresh start comes with the sunrise. I also like to keep a journal, mostly just to reflect on my thoughts and the things I'm grateful for. It's not something I do every day, but when I do, it helps me process the challenges I face and reminds me of why I chose this path. I also volunteer a few hours a month at a local food bank, which is something I've always felt strongly about. It's not just about giving back—it's about staying connected to the people I serve and remembering where I came from. I think those small, consistent habits are what keep me balanced and focused, even when life gets busy or overwhelming.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Brian Jackson: One of the more recent changes to my daily routine has been taking up gardening in the small space I have on the balcony above the bookstore. It started as a way to get some fresh air and disconnect from the screen time that comes with work, but it's turned into something more meaningful. I've been growing herbs and a few vegetables, which I use in my cooking on the weekends. It's been a nice way to slow down and be more present, especially with everything going on in the world. I also started a small compost bin, which I admit I'm still learning how to manage, but it's been a fun challenge. It's funny how something so simple can bring so much joy and a sense of accomplishment. I think it's a small step toward living more intentionally, and I'm glad I took it.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Brian Jackson: I don't have children, so I don't have a typical weekday routine for them, but I can imagine what it might look like based on the kids I've worked with over the years. From what I've seen, many children in our community start their day early, often helping out at home before heading off to school. After school, they might have activities like sports, music lessons, or after-school programs at the community center. I think it's important for kids to have structure and opportunities to explore their interests, even if they come from humble beginnings. I've always believed that education and extracurricular activities can be life-changing, and I try to support that in the work I do. While I don't have children of my own, I hope that the programs I help create can provide the same opportunities and stability that I was lucky to have growing up.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 11 to 15 has given me a lot to think about, especially how my life has unfolded in the context of the people and places that have shaped me. Reflecting on my family, friends, and neighborhood reminded me of how deeply connected I am to the roots I came from, even as I've built a life that's mine in its own way. I've always valued independence, and while I don't have a partner or children, I'm proud of the stability and purpose I've created for myself. Living in the same neighborhood where I grew up brings a sense of belonging and safety that I can't find anywhere else, and I appreciate the community that continues to support me. Even with the challenges of rising costs and the occasional feeling of being stuck in a routine, I remind myself that stability isn't always a bad thing. I've built a life that reflects my values, and I'm content with who I am and the path I've chosen.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Brian Jackson: In terms of my health, I'd say I've been pretty lucky. I don't have any major chronic conditions, and I try to take care of myself as best as I can. I've always been pretty active, even as a kid—I used to ride my bike everywhere, and I still enjoy walking or jogging around the neighborhood when I can. I try to eat healthy, mostly because I grew up with my mom's cooking, which was simple but nutritious. I do have a few aches and pains from working long hours at the nonprofit, especially in my back and shoulders, but I manage them with regular stretching and a few over-the-counter pain relievers when needed. I also make sure to get enough sleep, even if it's not always easy with the demands of work. I've never been a big fan of the gym, but I do enjoy the physical activity that comes with gardening and walking. Overall, I feel pretty good, and I try to stay proactive about my health rather than waiting until something goes wrong. I think it's important to take care of your body, especially when you're doing work that's as demanding as mine.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Brian Jackson: For me, what makes it easy to stay healthy is the rhythm of my daily life—the walks I take, the gardening, and the simple routines I've built over the years. I don't need a strict workout plan or a gym membership; I just need to move, even if it's just a few blocks around the neighborhood. What makes it harder is the stress that comes with the work I do. Sometimes, when I'm caught up in meetings or dealing with the complexities of policy, I forget to take breaks or eat properly. I've learned to set reminders to stretch or take a walk, but there are still days when I push through without realizing how much I'm wearing myself down. I think the key is balance—knowing when to push forward and when to step back. I've also started incorporating more mindfulness into my routine, like taking a few deep breaths before starting my day or before going to bed. It's not perfect, but it helps me stay grounded and reminds me that taking care of my health is just as important as the work I do for others.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Brian Jackson: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some recurring back pain that's gotten worse, especially after long days at work. I think it's from sitting at my desk for so many hours, even though I try to take breaks and stretch. I finally went to a physical therapist a few months ago, and it's been helping a bit. They gave me some exercises to strengthen my core and improve my posture, which I've been doing regularly. I also started using a standing desk at work, which has made a noticeable difference. It's been a reminder that even small changes can have a big impact on your well-being. I haven't been diagnosed with anything serious, but I've learned to listen to my body more and not ignore the signs when something feels off. It's not always easy, but I'm trying to be more proactive about my health now, especially since I know how important it is to be there for the people I work with and the community I care so much about.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Brian Jackson: Honestly, the back pain hasn't really gotten in the way of my work or daily life, but it has made me more aware of how important it is to take care of myself. I used to think I could push through anything, but now I realize that if I don't take the time to rest and recover, I won't be able to keep doing the work I care about. It's funny, because I've always been the one helping others manage their challenges, but now I'm learning that I need to be just as careful with my own health. I've started setting aside time each evening to do the exercises the physical therapist showed me, and I've even begun taking short breaks during the day to stretch or walk around the office. It's not always easy to slow down, especially when there's so much to do, but I've come to see it as part of the job—not just for the people I serve, but for myself too.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Brian Jackson: Over the past year, I've been feeling a mix of things—mostly steady, but with moments of reflection and growth. I think the pandemic really made me realize how much I value the little things: the quiet mornings, the conversations with friends, the sense of community here. I've been trying to be more present, more intentional with how I spend my time. There were definitely moments of stress, especially with the work I do, but I've also found a lot of peace in the routines I've built. I've been gardening more, which has been a real comfort. It's a way to slow down and connect with something tangible, something that doesn't rely on the chaos of the world. I've also been thinking a lot about where I am in life and what I want to prioritize moving forward. I don't know if I'm exactly where I thought I'd be at this point, but I feel like I'm exactly where I need to be. I'm content, and I'm grateful for the life I've built—flaws and all.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 16 to 20 has made me reflect on how my health and daily habits are deeply connected to the life I've built. I never thought much about my routines before, but now I see how they shape not just my physical well-being, but also my mental clarity and sense of purpose. Taking up gardening on my balcony has been a small but meaningful change—it's given me a way to slow down, connect with nature, and find joy in something simple. At the same time, I've had to confront the reality of my back pain and the need to take better care of my body. It's funny how the same lessons I've always tried to teach others—about balance, mindfulness, and self-care—now apply to me in a more personal way. I've realized that health isn't just about avoiding illness; it's about living intentionally and making choices that support both my work and my well-being. I'm still learning, but I'm grateful for the small steps I've taken to create a healthier, more balanced life.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Brian Jackson: I think I've been pretty lucky when it comes to mental health. I've never struggled with depression or anxiety in the way some people do, but I've had my moments of doubt—times when I questioned whether I was making the right choices or if I was doing enough for the people I care about. I think part of it comes from the weight of responsibility that comes with the work I do. There are days when I feel like I'm fighting an uphill battle, and it's easy to feel small in the face of all the challenges out there. But I've learned to lean on the people around me, to take a step back when I need to, and to remind myself that progress, even slow progress, is still progress. I've also started meditating a little bit, just a few minutes each morning, which helps me center myself before the day begins. I don't think I'm immune to stress or hardship, but I've built a life that gives me the tools to handle it—whether it's through my community, my routines, or just the simple act of taking care of myself.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Brian Jackson: For my family, the past year has been a mix of stability and quiet growth. My parents are both doing well—my mom still works part-time at the same store she's been at for years, and my dad enjoys his retirement, though he does help out with some odd jobs around the neighborhood. They've always been proud of me, even if they don't always understand the path I've taken. I think they're happy to see me settled and content, even if it's not the traditional life they might have imagined for me. My sister Claire has been busy with her work in New York, but we've managed to stay in touch, and I think she's starting to see the value in the life I've built. She's always been the adventurous one, but I think she's beginning to appreciate the strength and purpose that comes with a more grounded existence. Overall, I feel like my family is doing okay, and I'm grateful for the support they've always given me. Even if we're not all in the same place, we're still connected by the love and understanding that have always defined us.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Brian Jackson: I've always considered myself more of a spiritual person than religious. I don't follow any organized faith, and I never really connected with the formal aspects of religion growing up. But I do believe in something bigger than myself—maybe the idea that we're all connected, or that there's a kind of quiet strength in the world that helps people through tough times. I think that's why I've always been drawn to community work. It feels like a way of honoring that connection, of giving back in a way that makes sense to me. I don't go to church or pray in the traditional sense, but I do find moments of reflection in nature, in the simple things like watching the sunrise or feeling the rain on my skin. I think spirituality, for me, is more about being present and aware of the world around me, and knowing that even in the hardest times, there's something that keeps us going.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Brian Jackson: I don't use social media much, to be honest. I've always been more of a person who prefers face-to-face interactions or even just a phone call over scrolling through feeds. I think it's more about how I grew up—my parents didn't have much access to it when I was growing up, and I never really felt the need to jump on the bandwagon. That said, I do use Facebook occasionally to stay in touch with family and old friends. I've always found it easier to connect with people through shared experiences rather than curated posts. I follow a few local community pages and some environmental groups that align with my work, but I don't spend a lot of time on it. I think there's value in being present in the real world, and I've always found that my relationships are stronger when they're built on actual conversations rather than likes and comments. Plus, I get enough news from the local paper and the conversations I have with people around me. It's not that I'm against it—I just don't feel like it's necessary for me to be part of that digital world.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Brian Jackson: Honestly, I don't think I've ever relied on social media for emotional or financial support. I've always found that the people I know in real life—my family, my friends, the folks in my neighborhood—are more than enough. When things get tough, I lean on them, not on a screen. I know it's not the same for everyone, and I respect that some people find comfort in those platforms. But for me, it's about the connections that matter most—those that come with a handshake, a hug, or a real conversation over coffee. I've never felt the need to broadcast my struggles online or ask for help in a way that feels public. It's not that I don't need support—it's just that I've always believed in asking for it in person, where it feels more genuine and more meaningful.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 21 to 25 has made me reflect on how my health and mental well-being are deeply intertwined with the life I've built. I used to think of my back pain as just a minor inconvenience, something I could push through without much thought. But now I see it as a sign that my body is telling me to slow down and take better care of myself. It's funny how the same lessons I've always tried to teach others—about balance, mindfulness, and self-care—now apply to me in a more personal way. I've also come to realize that mental health isn't just about avoiding sadness or stress; it's about finding peace in the small moments, like the quiet mornings, the conversations with friends, and the sense of community that surrounds me. I've always believed in the power of connection, and it's comforting to know that I have people in my life who support me, even when I don't always ask for it. I'm still learning, but I'm grateful for the small steps I've taken to create a healthier, more balanced life—not just for my body, but for my mind and spirit as well.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Brian Jackson: In the past year, I've noticed that my stress levels have been more manageable, mostly because I've started to prioritize self-care in ways I didn't before. I used to think that stress was just part of the job, something I had to push through. But now I see it as a signal that I need to slow down and take a step back. I've been more intentional about setting boundaries at work, making sure I take regular breaks, and not letting my to-do list consume me. I've also found that my emotional coping strategies have shifted—where I used to rely on work or busyness to distract myself, I now find peace in the small things: reading a book on the balcony, talking with friends, or even just sitting in silence for a while. I've started journaling more, not just to reflect on my day but to process my feelings and thoughts. It's helped me see patterns in how I react to stress and given me tools to respond more thoughtfully. I'm not saying I'm stress-free, but I feel more in control of it now, and that makes all the difference.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Brian Jackson: In terms of making ends meet, my monthly budget is pretty straightforward, though it's always a balancing act. My biggest expenses are rent and groceries, which take up a good chunk of my income. I live in a small apartment above the bookstore, and while the rent is reasonable for this area, it's still a significant part of my budget. Groceries can be tight, especially with the rising costs, but I've learned to be pretty careful with my spending—planning meals, buying in bulk when I can, and trying to support local farmers' markets when I have the extra cash. Utilities and internet are also regular expenses, and I've had to cut back on some discretionary spending, like dining out or entertainment, to make sure I can cover the essentials. I also set aside a small amount each month for savings, just in case something unexpected comes up. It's not a huge income, but it's enough to live comfortably, and I try to be mindful of every dollar I spend. I've always believed that stability comes from being responsible with what you have, and I think that's something I've managed to do over the years.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Brian Jackson: Last month, my household spent just over $1,800, which is pretty much in line with what I usually spend. The bulk of that goes to rent, which is around $900, and groceries, which averaged about $400. I also spend roughly $150 on utilities and internet, and another $100 or so on transportation and miscellaneous expenses like books or supplies for work. I've been trying to be more mindful of my spending, especially with the rising costs, so I've cut back on things like eating out or buying new clothes. I also set aside about $100 each month for savings, which I know sounds small, but it helps me feel more secure. I've always believed that living within your means is the foundation of a stable life, and I think I've managed to do that without sacrificing the things that matter most to me.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Brian Jackson: We rent the apartment above the bookstore. It's a small space, but it's comfortable and convenient. I've been in the same place for a few years now, which has been nice for stability. Renting has always made more sense for me than owning—especially with the way things are changing in the neighborhood. I don't see myself buying a house anytime soon. I like the flexibility of renting, and it allows me to focus on other things, like my work and the community around me. Plus, living above the bookstore has its perks. I get to see Sam every day, and it's always nice to have a little connection to the place I grew up in.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Brian Jackson: Over the past year, my bills have had their ups and downs, mostly tied to the seasons and the usual rhythm of life here. In the winter, utilities like heating and electricity go up, which means my monthly bills feel a bit heavier. I've had to be more careful with the thermostat and make sure I'm not leaving lights or the heater on unnecessarily. On the flip side, summer brings higher air conditioning costs, and I've noticed that my electricity bill spikes a bit during those months too. Holidays have also had an impact—around Thanksgiving and Christmas, I tend to spend a little more on groceries and small gifts for friends or family, even if it's just a card or a homemade treat. I also noticed that when the local bookstore had its annual inventory sale, my expenses for books and supplies went down a bit, which was a nice surprise. Overall, I've tried to keep things as consistent as possible, but I've learned that some fluctuations are just part of the season and the life I've built here.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30 has made me reflect on how my family and my approach to social media are both rooted in the values I've always held close. My family, though not always in the same place, has always been a source of support and understanding, and I'm grateful for the stability and love they've given me throughout my life. It's comforting to know that even if we're not all living the same way, we're still connected by the same sense of care and respect. As for social media, I've always found that the real connections—the ones built through shared experiences and face-to-face conversations—are the ones that matter most. I don't feel the need to be part of the digital world in the way others are, and I think that's okay. What's important is that I stay true to who I am and the relationships that have shaped me, whether they're in person or in the quiet moments of reflection I find in my daily life.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Brian Jackson: I do have a savings account, though it's not a huge amount. I set aside about $100 each month, which might not sound like much, but it's a habit I've stuck with for years. I think it started when I was in college, realizing how quickly things can change and how important it is to have a little cushion. I don't save in any other way—no fancy investments or retirement funds, just that small, consistent amount. It's more about peace of mind than anything else. I know I could save more, but I also believe in living within my means and not sacrificing the things that matter most for the sake of accumulating wealth. For me, savings are about security, but also about knowing that I've done my part to prepare for the unexpected. It's not perfect, but it's something I'm proud of.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Brian Jackson: For me, saving has always been more about the rainy day kind of thing rather than big purchases like a home. I've never really seen myself as someone who needs to own property—I've always preferred the flexibility that renting gives me, especially with how things are changing in the neighborhood. That said, I do try to set money aside each month, not just for emergencies, but also as a way to remind myself that I'm responsible with what I have. I think it's easy to get caught up in the idea that saving is only for big goals, but for me, it's about the small, consistent choices that add up over time. I know I could save more, but I also believe in living within my means and not sacrificing the things that matter most for the sake of accumulating wealth. For me, savings are about security, but also about knowing that I've done my part to prepare for the unexpected. It's not perfect, but it's something I'm proud of.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Brian Jackson: My occupation has been in public policy, specifically working with community development initiatives through a nonprofit called Community Roots. The work I do is pretty varied—it involves a lot of policy research, community outreach, and program coordination. One of the most important parts of my job is getting out into the community, talking to people, and understanding their needs firsthand. I've always believed that policy isn't just about writing reports or passing legislation; it's about real people and real challenges. That's why I spend a lot of time visiting local schools, community centers, and even people's homes to hear their stories. I also work closely with local government officials to advocate for policies that support low-income families, especially in areas like housing and healthcare. The most rewarding part of the job is seeing the impact of the work we do—whether it's helping someone secure stable housing or ensuring a family has access to essential services. It's not always easy, and there are days when it feels like we're fighting an uphill battle, but I keep going because I know that even small changes can make a big difference in people's lives.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Brian Jackson: I usually work around 40 to 45 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the time of year or the projects we're working on. There are weeks when I'm buried in reports or preparing for meetings with city officials, and those days can stretch into the evenings. Other times, especially when we're out in the community doing outreach or organizing events, I might be on my feet all day, talking to people, listening to their stories, and helping them navigate the systems that can feel so overwhelming. I've always believed that the work I do isn't just about policy—it's about people, and that means being present, even if it means working a little longer than usual. I don't mind the hours as long as I know I'm making a difference, even in small ways.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Brian Jackson: No, I haven't had more than one job, though I've taken on some side projects here and there. For a while, I used to write articles for a local magazine on community issues, which was a nice way to stay engaged with the work I care about while also earning a little extra income. It wasn't a full-time gig, but it gave me a different perspective on the stories I was telling through my policy work. I also helped out with a few local events or workshops, mostly around education and civic engagement. It wasn't about making more money—it was about staying connected to the people and causes that matter to me. I think having that variety kept me grounded and reminded me why I chose this path in the first place. I've always believed that work should be meaningful, even if it's not always the most lucrative.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Brian Jackson: In total, my household made just under $3,200 in the past month. That comes from my full-time job at Community Roots, which pays a modest but steady salary, and the occasional freelance writing gigs I take on. I've always believed in living within my means, and while it's not a huge income, it's enough to cover my expenses and give me a little extra to save or spend on things that matter. I've never been one for luxury, and I think that's why I've managed to stay financially stable over the years. It's not about having more—it's about having enough to live a meaningful life, and I feel like I've found that balance.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Brian Jackson: I've been at Community Roots for about six years now, and it's been a journey of growth and purpose. The benefits of the job are pretty standard for a nonprofit—health insurance is the biggest one, though it's not the most comprehensive plan. We get a few weeks of paid vacation each year, and sick time is something we can use when needed. I also get a small stipend for professional development, which I've used to attend workshops on community engagement and policy advocacy. It's not the kind of job that offers a lot in terms of financial perks, but I've always valued the intangible benefits—the sense of making a difference, the relationships I've built with the people we serve, and the knowledge that my work is contributing to something bigger than myself. I think that's why I've stayed here all these years. It's not just a job; it's a way of life that aligns with who I am and what I believe in.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Brian Jackson: My relationships at work are pretty much what I've always valued—collaborative, respectful, and built on a shared sense of purpose. I've been lucky to work with a team of people who are just as passionate about the work as I am. My manager, Lisa, is someone I really respect. She's been with the organization for over a decade, and she has this way of balancing leadership with empathy. She doesn't just assign tasks; she listens, she asks questions, and she makes sure we're all aligned with the bigger picture. I think that's why I've stayed here for so long. As for my coworkers, we've developed a real camaraderie over the years. We're not just colleagues—we're friends who support each other through the ups and downs of this work. There are days when it feels overwhelming, especially when we're dealing with systemic issues that seem impossible to change, but knowing I'm not alone in this makes all the difference. I think that's what keeps me going—knowing that I'm part of something larger, and that I have people around me who believe in the same things I do.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Brian Jackson: My work schedule is pretty predictable, though there's always a bit of flexibility depending on the needs of the organization. I usually start around 8:30 a.m. and finish at 5 p.m., but I often stay a little later when we're preparing for a big meeting or finalizing a report. The flexibility comes in the sense that I can sometimes adjust my hours if I need to attend a community event or meet with someone in the neighborhood. That said, I do have to be pretty consistent with my time because we're often working on tight deadlines or coordinating with local officials. I think the predictability is what keeps me grounded—it gives me a sense of structure, which is important for someone like me who values stability. Plus, knowing that I can sometimes shift my hours to be more present in the community is a nice balance between work and the life I've built here.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Brian Jackson: Overall, I feel pretty content with my financial situation. It's not extravagant, and I know there are days when I wish I had more flexibility or could afford to take more risks, but I also know that I've built a life that's stable and meaningful. I don't have the kind of debt that so many people my age do, and I've managed to save a little each month, which gives me peace of mind. I've always believed that financial security isn't about having the most, but about having enough to live with purpose and support the people and causes that matter to me. I think I've found that balance, and I'm grateful for the life I've built on my own terms.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Brian Jackson: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My mom worked part-time at a local store, and my dad was a construction worker. They both had pretty steady jobs, though neither of them went to college. I remember seeing my dad come home tired but proud after long days on the job site, and my mom always made sure we had meals on the table, even if it was just simple food. They never had a lot, but they always made do. I think that's where I got my sense of responsibility and the belief that hard work can get you far. They didn't have the advantages I have now, but they gave me the foundation to build my own life. I've always been grateful for that, and I think it's why I've never taken my opportunities for granted.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Brian Jackson: My dad worked as a construction worker, which meant he was always on job sites building homes, schools, and other structures. He didn't have a lot of formal education, but he had a real knack for figuring things out on the spot. His most important duties were making sure the work was done right, even if it meant staying late or working through the rain. I remember seeing him come home with calloused hands and a tired look in his eyes, but he always had a smile for us. He believed in the work he did, even if it wasn't always the most glamorous. My mom worked part-time at a local grocery store, and her most important duties were making sure the shelves were stocked, the registers were running smoothly, and the customers felt welcome. She had a way of making even the most mundane tasks feel meaningful. I think that's where I got my sense of purpose—watching them both work hard, not for recognition, but for the simple joy of providing for their family. They never had much, but they gave me everything I needed to build my own life.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Brian Jackson: My dad worked for a local construction company that handled a lot of residential and commercial projects around Charleston. They didn't have a fancy name or a lot of resources, but they got the job done. He was part of a crew that built homes, fixed up old buildings, and even worked on some community projects like repairing sidewalks or building new community centers. It wasn't the most glamorous work, but it was steady, and he took pride in knowing that his work helped people. My mom worked at a small grocery store that had been around for decades. It wasn't a big chain—it was one of those family-owned places where everyone knew your name. She was responsible for stocking shelves, ringing people up, and making sure the store ran smoothly. She had a real knack for connecting with customers, and I think that's why she stayed there for so long. Both of them worked hard, not for recognition or wealth, but for the simple joy of providing for their family. I think that's where I got my sense of purpose—watching them both work hard, not for recognition, but for the simple joy of providing for their family. They never had much, but they gave me everything I needed to build my own life.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Brian Jackson: Looking a few years ahead, I hope to continue living in this neighborhood, surrounded by the people and places that have shaped me. I don't see myself moving away or changing my path drastically—I think I've found a rhythm that works for me, and I'm content with that. I'd like to keep growing in my work, maybe take on more leadership within the nonprofit or even start a small initiative that focuses on youth education or community gardening. I think those are areas where I can make a real difference, especially with the kids in the neighborhood who are just starting to find their way. I also hope to keep up the gardening on my balcony, maybe expand it a bit, and share what I've learned with others who might be interested. I don't know if I'll ever have a partner or children, but I hope to keep the relationships I have strong and meaningful. I want to be someone others can count on, just like the people who supported me when I was growing up. I think that's the biggest hope I have—for my life to be a reflection of the values I've always held close, and for the work I do to make a small but lasting impact on the people around me.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Brian Jackson: What I value the most in my life is the sense of connection—whether it's with the people in my neighborhood, the work I do, or the simple things that remind me I'm part of something bigger. I value the relationships I've built over the years, even if they're not always the ones people expect. I value the stability of living in a place I know, where I feel safe and grounded. I value the work I do because it allows me to give back in a way that feels meaningful, even if it's not always easy. And I value the small, quiet moments—the sunrise, the sound of rain, the conversations with friends—that remind me to be present. I think life is about more than just achieving things or having more; it's about being rooted in what truly matters, and I'm grateful for the life I've built on those values.
